metadata.title: Sectioning Airbnb Neighborhoods in Tokyo: Survey the Surroundings | by Fuaddi Yustindra | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Sectioning Airbnb Neighborhoods in Tokyo: Survey the Surroundings
metadata.description: Despite rising tension with the government authority in recent years, Tokyo has been a growing market for property owners renting out their space for the public; 民泊 or minpaku as they would call in…

all_paragraphs: Despite rising tension with the government authority in recent years, Tokyo has been a growing market for property owners renting out their space for the public; 民泊 or minpaku as they would call in Japanese. Airbnb, just as in other major cities, is among the popular platforms to find one, especially for foreigners who possess little or no local language understanding.

When arriving at Airbnb, people tend to wonder what are some good spots nearby. Hidden underrated sushi bars, authentic local ramen stalls, or maybe those ‘grammable Japanesque cafes are waiting to be discovered. Quick Google search will do, but what if we could explore what kind of places are there in which area before even booking the place? Or find out areas with similar characteristics but cost less? We probably could save more time on deciding where to go and even plan our trip better. This light project aims to answer that question. It’s not only targeting travelers, but also might be useful for those interested in running the lodging or related business around the proximity, or even for people who consider living in the world’s most populous metropolitan city and wonder what the neighborhoods look like.

Inside Airbnb has one of the most updated databases for any Airbnb cities in the world, and it’s free; thanks to their scraping tool that managed to extract texts from the relatively complex HTML structure of the Airbnb webpage. After grabbing only the necessary data for the analysis, the data consisting of 13367 listings (as of November 2019) would look like this:

Then I aggregated the data to find out the number of listings, average price, and latitude/longitude coordinate of each neighborhood. To add some more spice, I did a quick BeautifulSoup scraping on the Special Wards of Tokyo Wikipedia page containing population and area data of the city’s administrative 23 wards.

Subsequently, based on the coordinates, I retrieved a maximum of 100 recommended places for each area within walking distance radius (less than 1km) using Foursquare API. There might be some areas that are less concentrated than the others, therefore having fewer spots surrounding. I found it interesting to see the obtained results as I didn’t know some quite nice places around despite living within the area for years now. Displayed below are the first few rows of 2216 records collected. We would look up more on the venue category to have a glance at the surroundings and answer the project question. So let’s get going to further analysis.
The chart below sums up all the information and gives us a glimpse of the comparison between the wards. I am using Plotly for the visualization, so feel free to hover around.

Overall, Tokyo listings cost 12k~15k JPY ($110~140) per night on average. It’s relatively equal or lower than average in other world’s major cities but it’s been actually getting pricier since last year due to rising demand ahead of Olympics Games this summer.

Area and population seem to be well-correlated as Nerima, Adachi, Edogawa, and Ota are in roughly equal size and color. It’s also interesting to see Bunkyo as the most expensive ward although it sits at bottom 3 for the number of listings. Besides, a spike on Edogawa price despite being on par in terms of population and area with 2 cheapest regions, is probably due to its easy access to Tokyo Disney Resort as well as to the city center. 5 outliers are easily identified for having ±1000~ listings; there seems to be an apparent reason for that which we’ll see in the next few lines.

You might be wondering where most of Tokyo’s Airbnb listings are concentrated. So here’s the map showing the apartment locations (smaller radius means less costly) and the 23 special wards pointed by the marker icons.

Roughly there are 3 big groups and a few smaller clusters of listings. The one at 4 o’clock position of Nakano sign there is Shinjuku, the busiest district in the country and also where ~17% of Tokyo listings are located. Having the city’s central station and lots of attractions could be the main reason why rental apartments are bunched there. Slightly to the north, we could see the second packed area — Toshima — home to the famous Ikebukuro district. It’s one of the main hubs connecting Tokyo and the neighboring suburbs as well as among convenient areas to live. The last group is situated on the east side where Taito and Sumida based. The must-visit Asakusa Shinsoji Temple and Tokyo Skytree never fail to attract a vast number of tourists there every single day. I am not quite familiar with the locale around but I heard more influx are coming to reside, thanks to reasonable rent and improving infrastructure.

In dataset 3, there are 242 unique categories with ‘Convenience Store’, ‘Ramen Restaurant’, ‘Japanese Restaurant’ (you don’t say), ‘Cafe’, and ‘Sake Bar’ top the list. Random categories such as ‘Well’, ‘Belarusian Restaurant’, and ‘Intersection’’ are also found in the list.

To figure out what the neighborhood looks like, I listed up the most common venue categories in each ward then used the relative frequency values for the segmenting part. The aggregated table is a sparse 23×243 matrix.

This time I would just fit the k-means clustering algorithm to find similar neighborhood groups as it’s common and powerful for unsupervised tasks. I choose 4 as the optimum number of k after examining the elbow method and silhouette score. Other features in dataset 2 aren’t included in fitting the model to avoid demographic and spatial noise. But those are instead useful in comparing the difference between clusters as shown in the table below:
The first and second cluster look like this,
and here are the remaining third and fourth.
For those who are not familiar with Tokyo, it should be difficult to see the geographical pattern just from looking at the table above, so the following refined visualization might help.

We have observed interesting findings only from a relatively small dataset from basic geospatial data, Airbnb listings, and Foursquare. In the brief check part, you could have a big picture of which neighborhood suits your needs. For instance, if you want to stay at a place in the common area and are willing to be charged more than average, set your filter search to one of the top 5 wards in the number of listings. Or those who could compromise spending a bit more transits and commute time for cheaper rents may find places around Nerima and Adachi suitable for them.

The clustering result also turned out to be surprisingly good. Without putting geocoordinate data into k-means fitting, the outcome seemingly found the way to form segments that group neighborhood with its spatially close counterpart. If I may include my own domain knowledge, cluster 1 consists of the outskirts, cluster 2 represents the traveler-friendly area, cluster 3 seems to be the all-rounder (business, shopping, tourism), cluster 4 is pretty much random. Seeing further, each cluster could be characterized as below:

When booking Airbnb or other rental lodgings, it might be useful in understanding the characteristics and the surroundings. You know which neighborhoods that may fit and not fit your preferences, by considering the location, average price, and/or population density, too. Popular areas like Shinjuku, Shibuya, Ikebukuro, Ueno, and Asakusa are where the rental apartments are condensed. However, less famous neighborhoods are also worth trying and they cost comparatively less; perhaps you’ll find hidden gems and local experiences along the way. The data reveals that the Japanese capital could diverge into 4 zones. The suburbs? The travelers’ swarm? The all-in-one districts? Or the average locales? Which one would you prefer?
This writing is part of the applied capstone project of the IBM Data Science Professional Certificate.
